analytic.title: Authoris votum! At the Poeticall shrine of IVPITER XENIVS, on the Altar there found written in a scroll, with this Inscription:

monogr.title: The history of Great Britanie : from the first peopling of this island to this present raigne of or [sic] happy and peacefull monarke K: Iames, by Will: Slatyer
monogr.author: Slatyer, William

div.head: Authoris votum! At the Poeticall shrine of IVPITER XENIVS, on the Altar there found written in a scroll, with this Inscription:

Vniuersis Iouis ac Pallados filijs; sanctis Musarum alumnis,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : vt & Lectori candido, salutem:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
div.l: ZEus Xenius, or thou friendly Ioue,
That strangers do'st and Pilgrimes loue,
To thee, my humble Muse, her song
Should offer, rapt from Cradle yong,
Where shee began these Odes to treate

In pleasant flowry Sommers
Alluding to the name of Somerset, Vnde ex humili Pago Tykenham nominato, originem duxit, quâ propè Bristoliam flaua Sabrina fluit. seate:

Neare that Faire-place, beene with bright Bright-stow, the name of Bristow, signifying a faire place; it being a pleasant site, and the chiefe Emporium, of all the townes seated on the Seuerne, and on the coasts of Wales beames
The pride of sandy Seuernes streames,
Sweet Cells! though not compar'd with those

Neare Ouses-fourd, where faire Tame
Ouse-fourd the true interpretation of the name of Oxford so called of the Riuer Ouse, running by it. flowes,
Whith'r brought, my Muse, some part full faine
Chaunts of her yet vnheard-off straine.
Thence siluer-founted Crystall Thames,
His fore-head deckt, cleare lympid' streame
With dangling Reedes, and flaggy Flowers,
Conuay'd her downe to old Luds Some will haue London to be anciently so called, viz. Ludstowne and Caer-Lud. bowers,
Where shee beheld, with wondring eyes
Both Cities pride and Courtly guise,
Whom noblest Nymphs that haunt the place,
Gently daign'd more then lookt-for grace.
Next Courtly troupes, the Countrey traines,
Did heare her sing, and those wild plaines
That thee, deare Daniel, so did blesse,

And rauishing notions first So Master Daniel writes of himselfe, and Wilton, of which Wilton, Wiltshire, (alluded by some from the wild plaines, quasi Wilde-shire) takes her name; Vbi in villâ Bedwyn antiquitus totius Comitatus paenè nulli secundâ, nec satis ignobili, tam ob incolarum Rusticitatem, quam ob suarum olim celebritatum iacturam, aliquandiu Moram traxit. impresse
Into thy soule! from whence shee went
To Cambers wild, and flowry Kent,
Rhutupian farthest shores i'th East.

Old holy Dauids shrine Rhutupiae or the coasts of Douer, and Sandwich East, & Saint Dauids called Meneuia, in the West, are, and are ordinarily accounted the vtmost limits those wayes of great Brytaine. by-west
Did heare her tunes, and Odes shee ended
In those well hop't-of bowers entended
To Phoebus honour, of King IAMES
Nam'd; west of London by faire Chelsey Colledge is K. Iames foundation, and in the Patent so called of his name. Thames!
From Somerset, her natiue home
Thus t'Ouse-fourd rapt, and Luds faire Towne,
To those wilde plaines, and whither th'age
Last past vow'd holyVnde, Roma semel quantum, bis dat Meneuia tātum. Pilgrimage
T' old Dauids cells, where Phoebus falles,
Saint, Prophet, Priest, and Prince of Wales;
And from fard'st west to th' Orient,

As farre as rich vnhealthyThe ordinary saying amongst vs, affirming the farther parts of Kent to be wealthy though vnhealthy, the middest healthy not wealthy, but both healthy and wealthy neare London.
Kent.
If friendly fauour moue your brest
To entertaine this wandring guest
For your delight, or more grac't see
Since Albion hight! thus farre yet wee
Curteously salute you, and your loue
Zeus Xenius Guerdon't, gentle Ioue.
